awd_titl_txt: ATE Collaborative Outreach and Engagement Project
awd_abstract_narration:
The ATE Collaborative Outreach and Engagement (ACOE) project will implement a strategy and plan to raise awareness of the National Science Foundation's Advanced Technological Education (ATE) program, the centers and projects the program funds, and the valuable resources these grantees develop. This awareness will help build partnerships and collaborations, disseminate innovative ATE resources, and create synergy around the program's efforts. In addition, the deliverables of this project will help further the case for the critical U.S. economic need for technician education and the important role community colleges play in the context of the ATE program and beyond. The project will allow the whole community - from small projects to national centers - to highlight individual activities and simultaneously to explain the broader impact of the ATE program.

The ACOE project will improve the skills and knowledge of technicians and technical educators by (1) increasing awareness of the resources available from NSF ATE grantees; (2) fostering collaborative activities among centers and projects to reach more individual educators and students, community colleges, and employers; (3) enhancing decision maker knowledge of the NSF ATE program; and (4) facilitating partnerships between industry and other stakeholders and those in the ATE community. The project focuses on providing opportunities for interaction and collaboration in tandem with high-quality materials that will increase the rigor, relevance, intensity, and cross-transfer of content knowledge, pedagogy, and technical skills in advanced technology fields. Collectively, the project will strengthen the ATE community's outreach efforts through a mixed-media approach to disseminate information and effectively interact with stakeholders at all levels including employers, administrators, educators, industry partners, and students.

por.por_cntn:
The ATE Collaborative Outreach and Engagement Project DUE#1723419 was a partner in a two-part collaborative grant project with the University of Wisconsin Madison DUE#1723674 and the project partnership goals were to:

 1. Inform stakeholders of the resources and services offered by the funded projects and centers in the ATE program.

 2. Support grantee outreach efforts by creating materials and resources they can easily adapt and integrate into their own work. (This Goal #2 work was the focus of partner UW-Madison DUE#1723674)

 3. Facilitate collaboration and engagement within and beyond the ATE community.

This project informed stakeholders of the resources and services offered through ATE centers and projects through conference presentations and by hosting exhibit booths at national, state, and regional conferences and other events. Conference presentations focused on sharing information about the ATE program, the ATE solicitation and funding tracks, the technology areas supported, ATE mentoring initiatives, the PAPPG, and selected ATE projects such as ATE Central, the Journal of Advanced Technological Education and the EvaluATE center. The ATE focused conference presentations were attended by at total of 249 people. Fifty-five of the ATE Community exhibits were hosted live and 10 virtual exhibits were hosted during the COVID years. The ATE Community exhibits were visited by over 2800 conference and event attendees. The live ATE Community exhibits included ATE banner stands, informational flyers about ATE Centers and projects, ATE mentoring initiative flyers, EvaluATE Survey informational flyers, the ATE Impacts book, Journals of ATE, and a continuous informational PowerPoint presentation.

As a result of efforts to facilitate collaboration and engagement within and beyond the ATE Community, new partnerships were formed, mentoring relationships were developed, collaborations were initiated, and networking connections were established. Exhibit booth visitors were informed about the mentoring opportunities for leadership and proposal development, and many participated in the mentoring initiatives. Some of the exhibit booth visitors or presentation attendees have submitted ATE proposals and have received ATE awards and others have joined collaboratives or partnered on projects with similar technologies.

 


Last Modified: 11/02/2023
Modified by: Gregory G Kepner
